sampling

Source: vignettes/articles/sampling.Rmd
sampling.Rmd

Within experimental designs, sampling via a given method is considered similarly to other “building blocks” manipulations. Conceptually, they also:

  • take a theoretical scanList as an input
  • alter it in some way:
    • group-scan sampling can lead to missing some edges: they are turned into NA in the scanList regardless of them being 1 or 0 originally
    • focal(-scan) sampling allows to sample all edges involving the focal, but misses all the others: they are also turned to NAs
  • and return an empirical scanList

Designin a sampling method

Designing a sampling method - or creating a expDesign object in SimuNet - relies on design_sampling() and design_exp():

  • design_sampling() tailors a sampling function of scanList
  • design_exp(), a general wrapper to create a sequence of experimental manipulations, takes the function returned by design_sampling() to include the sampling as part of the manipulation sequence.

Sampling can be only part of the overall experimental design, and for instance follow a sequence of other manipulations. See them in action in the following examples!

Group-scan sampling

Group-scan sampling is the act of looking at the whole group during scans, and seeing who is associated/interacting with whom.

  • Empirically, the scan can diverge from theory by missing individuals and/or edges.
  • Internally, group-scan sampling method:
    • requires setting the argument method = "group"
    • relies on a edge observation probability matrix, named obs.P, and stored in resulting scanList’s attributes list attrs.
library(SimuNet)
design_sampling(method = "group",sampling = "random")
#> Theoretical scanList ->
#>  ------------
#>  group-scan sampling: random ->
#>  ------------
#>  empirical scanList
#> 
#> See `$FUN.seq` for the functions source code.

The returned function can be passed to design_exp()

group.rand <- design_sampling(method = "group",sampling = "random")
 # or 
group.fun <- design_sampling(method = "group",sampling = "random")
group.rand <- design_exp(group.fun)

Let’s apply it to a scanList:

set.seed(42)
n <- 5L
samp.effort <- 100L
Adj <- sample(1:samp.effort,n * n) |>
  matrix(nrow = 5,dimnames = list(letters[1:n],letters[1:n]))
Adj[lower.tri(Adj,diag = TRUE)] <- 0L
Adj
#>   a   b  c  d  e
#> a 0 100 37 27 58
#> b 0   0 20 36 42
#> c 0   0  0  5 93
#> d 0   0  0  0 30
#> e 0   0  0  0  0

sL.group <- simunet(Adj,samp.effort,"upper",10,group.rand)
sL.group
#> 
#> scan: 1               
#> a . NA NA NA NA
#> b .  . NA  .  .
#> c .  .  . NA NA
#> d .  .  .  . NA
#> e .  .  .  .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . 1 NA  . NA
#> b . . NA  . NA
#> c . .  . NA NA
#> d . .  .  .  .
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10              
#> a . NA .  1 NA
#> b .  . .  .  .
#> c .  . . NA NA
#> d .  . .  .  .
#> e .  . .  .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.group |> attrs("theoretical.scanList")  # see what intermediate scanList was generated
#> 
#> scan: 1           
#> a . 1 1 . 1
#> b . . . . .
#> c . . . . 1
#> d . . . . .
#> e . . . . .
#> 
#> scan: 2           
#> a . 1 . . .
#> b . . . . 1
#> c . . . . 1
#> d . . . . .
#> e . . . . .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10           
#> a . 1 . 1 1
#> b . . . . .
#> c . . . . 1
#> d . . . . .
#> e . . . . .
sL.group |> attrs("obs.P")                 # see what obs.P was used
#> 
#> Weighted adjacency matrix                                           
#> a . 0.3170534 0.1161747 0.7297301 0.4803101
#> b . .         0.1861022 0.4118721 0.4274945
#> c . .         .         0.4140497 0.1364904
#> d . .         .         .         0.8246794
#> e . .         .         .         .

sL <- simunet(Adj,samp.effort,"upper",10)
sL |> perform_exp(group.rand)
#> 
#> scan: 1              
#> a . NA .  1  1
#> b .  . . NA NA
#> c .  . .  . NA
#> d .  . .  . NA
#> e .  . .  .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . 1 NA  . NA
#> b . .  . NA NA
#> c . .  .  . NA
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10            
#> a . 1 1 . NA
#> b . . . . NA
#> c . . . 1 NA
#> d . . . . NA
#> e . . . .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList

Types of group-scan sampling

obs.P can be defined via several routines

Random probabilities

Like in the previous example, observation probabilities can be determined at random. Input sampling as the character string "random"

group.rand <- design_sampling("group",sampling = "random") |> design_exp()

Constant probability

All probabilities can be set to a constant probability. Input this constant as the sampling argument:

group.cst <-
  design_sampling("group",sampling = 0.8) |> # an edge has 80% chances of being observed
  design_exp()
group.cst
#> Theoretical scanList ->
#>  ------------
#>  group-scan sampling: constant ->
#>  ------------
#>  empirical scanList
#> 
#> See `$FUN.seq` for the functions source code.
sL.cst <- sL |> perform_exp(group.cst)
sL.cst
#> 
#> scan: 1            
#> a . 1 . 1  1
#> b . . . 1  .
#> c . . . .  1
#> d . . . . NA
#> e . . . .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . NA NA . NA
#> b .  .  . 1  1
#> c .  .  . .  .
#> d .  .  . . NA
#> e .  .  . .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10           
#> a . 1 1 . .
#> b . . . . .
#> c . . . 1 1
#> d . . . . .
#> e . . . . .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.cst |> count_nonNA()
#> 
#> Weighted adjacency matrix             
#> a . 6 8  9  8
#> b . . 9 10  9
#> c . . .  8 10
#> d . . .  .  7
#> e . . .  .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList

Determined from a user-defined function

By inputting a function of Adj returning a similarly-dimensioned probability matrix, you can design several routines. To do so, pass the function as the samplingargument

central.bias_fun <- function(Adj) {
  str <- 
    Adj |>
    igraph::graph.adjacency(mode = "upper",weighted = TRUE) |> 
    igraph::strength()
  obs.P <- str %o% str
  diag(obs.P) <- 0
  obs.P / (max(obs.P) + 1)
}
central.bias_fun(Adj) # 
#>           a         b         c         d         e
#> a 0.0000000 0.8878744 0.6950532 0.4394530 0.9999798
#> b 0.8878744 0.0000000 0.6199123 0.3919446 0.8918739
#> c 0.6950532 0.6199123 0.0000000 0.3068253 0.6981841
#> d 0.4394530 0.3919446 0.3068253 0.0000000 0.4414325
#> e 0.9999798 0.8918739 0.6981841 0.4414325 0.0000000

group.bias <-
  design_sampling("group",sampling = central.bias_fun) |>
  design_exp()

sL.bias <- sL |> perform_exp(group.bias)
sL.bias
#> 
#> scan: 1             
#> a . 1 .  1  1
#> b . . .  1  .
#> c . . . NA  1
#> d . . .  . NA
#> e . . .  .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . 1  . NA  .
#> b . . NA  1  1
#> c . .  . NA  .
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10             
#> a . 1  1  . .
#> b . . NA  . .
#> c . .  . NA 1
#> d . .  .  . .
#> e . .  .  . .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.bias |> count_nonNA()
#> 
#> Weighted adjacency matrix            
#> a . 8 7 3 10
#> b . . 3 8  8
#> c . . . .  8
#> d . . . .  4
#> e . . . .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.bias |> attrs("obs.P")
#>   a         b         c         d         e
#> a 0 0.8878744 0.6950532 0.4394530 0.9999798
#> b 0 0.0000000 0.6199123 0.3919446 0.8918739
#> c 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.3068253 0.6981841
#> d 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.4414325
#> e 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> attr(,"sampling_fun")
#> function(Adj) {
#>   str <- 
#>     Adj |>
#>     igraph::graph.adjacency(mode = "upper",weighted = TRUE) |> 
#>     igraph::strength()
#>   obs.P <- str %o% str
#>   diag(obs.P) <- 0
#>   obs.P / (max(obs.P) + 1)
#> }
#> <bytecode: 0x0000000023da5618>
#> attr(,"sampling")
#> [1] "function"

sL |> scale_scans()
#> 
#> Scaled weighted adjacency matrix                 
#> a . 1 0.3 0.1 0.4
#> b . . 0.1 0.5 0.4
#> c . . .   0.2 0.9
#> d . . .   .   0.2
#> e . . .   .   .  
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob summed.scanList sampled
sL.bias |> scale_scans()
#> 
#> Scaled weighted adjacency matrix                       
#> a . 1 0.143 0.333 0.400
#> b . . 0.333 0.625 0.375
#> c . . .       NaN 0.875
#> d . . .     .     0.250
#> e . . .     .     .    
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList summed.scanList sampled

Focal(-scan) sampling

Focal(-scan) sampling is the act of following a focal individual, and record all associations/interactions involving it. a focal-scan sampling would be recording data “on the tick”, but focal scans can also be defined as continuous. We argue that by dividing a continuous focal sampling into segment, one can “binarize” a continuous scan into a scan equivalent, should it require dividing the continuous scan into the smallest segments sampling resolution allows (e.g. each minute).

  • Empirically, the scan can diverge from theory by showing only edges involving the focal.
  • Internally, group-scan sampling method:
    • requires setting the argument method = "focal"
    • relies on a focal selection probability vector, leading to drawing a focalList, and stored in resulting scanList’s attributes list attrs.
## randomly select focals
focal.rand <- design_sampling(method = "focal",sampling = "random") |>
  design_exp()

sL.foc <- sL |> perform_exp(focal.rand)
sL.foc
#> 
#> scan: 1              
#> a . 1 NA NA NA
#> b . .  .  1  .
#> c . .  . NA NA
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . 1 NA NA NA
#> b . .  .  1  1
#> c . .  . NA NA
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10              
#> a . 1  1  .  .
#> b . . NA NA NA
#> c . .  . NA NA
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob focalList theoretical.scanList
sL.foc |> attrs("focalList")
#> b b e d a d c b a a 
#> 2 2 5 4 1 4 3 2 1 1 
#> attr(,"sampling")
#> [1] "random"

Types of focal-scan sampling

focalList can be defined via several routines

Random probabilities

Like in the previous example, focals can be selected at random. Input sampling as the character string "random"

## randomly select focals
focal.rand <- design_sampling(method = "focal",sampling = "random") |>
  design_exp()

Even focal list

Efforts can be made to draw a focal list as evenly as possible (each node is sampled almost as many time). Input sampling as the character string "even" (the default).

## randomly select focals
focal.even <- design_sampling(method = "focal",sampling = "even") |>
  design_exp()

sL.even <- sL |> perform_exp(focal.even)
sL.even
#> 
#> scan: 1              
#> a . NA . NA NA
#> b .  . . NA NA
#> c .  . .  .  1
#> d .  . .  . NA
#> e .  . .  .  .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . NA . NA NA
#> b .  . . NA NA
#> c .  . .  .  .
#> d .  . .  . NA
#> e .  . .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10              
#> a . 1  1  .  .
#> b . . NA NA NA
#> c . .  . NA NA
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob focalList theoretical.scanList
sL.even |> attrs("focalList")
#> c c a d e b b e d a 
#> 3 3 1 4 5 2 2 5 4 1 
#> attr(,"sampling")
#> [1] "even"

Determined from a user-defined function

By inputting a function of Adj returning a probability vector (which length is the number of nodes), you can design several focal selection routines. To do so, pass the function as the samplingargument

trait_bias <- function(Adj) {
  n <- nrow(Adj)
  1:n # imagine the node index to be a trait that bias (favor) the selection of the node as focal
}
trait_bias(Adj) # 
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5

group.bias <-
  design_sampling("group",sampling = central.bias_fun) |>
  design_exp()

sL.bias <- sL |> perform_exp(group.bias)
sL.bias
#> 
#> scan: 1           
#> a . 1 . 1 1
#> b . . . 1 .
#> c . . . . 1
#> d . . . . .
#> e . . . . .
#> 
#> scan: 2              
#> a . NA .  .  .
#> b .  . .  1  1
#> c .  . . NA  .
#> d .  . .  . NA
#> e .  . .  .  .
#> 
#> ... ( 7  more scans)
#> 
#> scan: 10              
#> a . 1 NA NA  .
#> b . .  . NA  .
#> c . .  . NA  1
#> d . .  .  . NA
#> e . .  .  .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.bias |> count_nonNA()
#> 
#> Weighted adjacency matrix            
#> a . 9 9 4 10
#> b . . 7 5  8
#> c . . . 3 10
#> d . . . .  2
#> e . . . .  .
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList
sL.bias |> attrs("obs.P")
#>   a         b         c         d         e
#> a 0 0.8878744 0.6950532 0.4394530 0.9999798
#> b 0 0.0000000 0.6199123 0.3919446 0.8918739
#> c 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.3068253 0.6981841
#> d 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.4414325
#> e 0 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000
#> attr(,"sampling_fun")
#> function(Adj) {
#>   str <- 
#>     Adj |>
#>     igraph::graph.adjacency(mode = "upper",weighted = TRUE) |> 
#>     igraph::strength()
#>   obs.P <- str %o% str
#>   diag(obs.P) <- 0
#>   obs.P / (max(obs.P) + 1)
#> }
#> <bytecode: 0x0000000023da5618>
#> attr(,"sampling")
#> [1] "function"

sL |> scale_scans()
#> 
#> Scaled weighted adjacency matrix                 
#> a . 1 0.3 0.1 0.4
#> b . . 0.1 0.5 0.4
#> c . . .   0.2 0.9
#> d . . .   .   0.2
#> e . . .   .   .  
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob summed.scanList sampled
sL.bias |> scale_scans()
#> 
#> Scaled weighted adjacency matrix                     
#> a . 1 0.222 0.250 0.4
#> b . . 0.143 0.600 0.5
#> c . . .     0.333 0.9
#> d . . .     .     .  
#> e . . .     .     .  
#> 
#> 
#> Hidden attributes: scanList.type raw.scanList Adj samp.effort n.scans mode Adj.subfun edge.Prob obs.P theoretical.scanList summed.scanList sampled
